Administration Does It Again
New Language Labs Fraud Charged In Allocations
In Financial Squeeze Of Kosher Food Plan Funds
As Dean Hides Facts
An inadequate amount of funds
has been allocated for operation
of the language laboratories
which opened for the first time
on Monday, October 2.
Allyn Kimball, Dean of the
Faculty of Arts and Sciences, refused to disclose the actual operating cost of the lab for the
year. He felt that it was not the
business of the students to know
about these matters.

By DENNIS ESTIS
A News-Letter investigation has
revealed the University's fraudulent acquisition of money from
members of the dormitory's
Kosher food plan,
Rabbi Bertrand G. Fink, adviser to the Kosher Dining Hall
and Jewish Student Association,
charged that the University had
demonstrated "ruthlessness" and
"uncooperativeness" in relation
to the plan.
Under the Kosher plan, a memher pays an extra S50 above the
S900 which most dormitory residents pay. Out of this $950, food
and related costs account for
$558.
Extortion at the Hop
From the S550, the University
gives the Kosher Dining Hall a
little over $300, which plus the
extra S50 paid by members, is the
bare cost for food. The remaining
$240 is kept by, Hopkins.
As a result the Kosher Dining

Hall is losing $175 on each member. The plan would have to receive $500 per student to break
even.
The University does not give
the plan member anything for
the money which it keeps. The
plant manager, Wesley Taylor, under whose domain the food plan
comes, claims that there is a cer•
tam n fixed overhead which does
not change whether or not the
students eat in the Dining Hall
or in the Kosher plan.
"Ashamed of the Truth"
However, Rabbi Fink claimed
that the University was hiding
the real facts because they were
"ashamed of the truth."
Rabbi Fink also charged that
the "University is taking S240
and not giving the student a
dime's worth of food."
He cited the fact that other
universities which have Kosher
eating plans give all the funds
allocated toward food and re-

lated costs to the Kosher Dining
Hall. He noted the programs at
University of Maryland, Syracuse
and the University of Pennsylvania.

the largest of its kind in the

Rabbi Fink is still allocated a
"full 100% credit" by the University.
The Hopkins Kosher Dining
Hall came into existence last year
and served six dinners a week.
Dorm residents who joined the
plan were allowed to eat all
other meals in the main dining
room.
Plan Expanded
This year, the Kosher plan was
expanded to serving twelve meals
a week: six lunches and six dinners. However, no provision was

The Waiting Wall
In a revealing statement last week, Dean Allyn Kimball both substantiated our suspicions and damned the
administration at the same time. Students, according to
the good Dean, should keep their noses out of such
matters as institutional finances and mind their own
business.
This unfortunate expression of the subconscious
reaffirms our view that the student is only an incidental guest at Hopkins. It would be wise to remember
that an administration is only a glorified janitor, making sure all the parts are running to the satisfaction of
the scholars and students.
There is a phenomenon in social theory that explains the syndrome of the Hopkins administration. It
seems that organizations are created to reach goals.
When they lose sight of their goal, or become sidetracked, the organization often works only to perpetuate itself. Apparently this is what has happened to the
Hopkins administration—a situation whereby both student and scholar are seriously threatened.
We humble students have entrusted this institution
vilith the responsibility to educate us, and it seems that
at a crisp $2,000 per annum the administration could
accommodate us. Instead, at every corner we see blunder
after blunder. And when we ask why, we are told it is
not our business. What goes on behind the green door?
For instance, why does Whitehead Hall and Plant
Manager Wesley Taylor siphon off $240 from the food
allowance of subscribers to the Kosher Dining Hall?
"For overhead" we are told. What overhead? The students are paying for everything in this project.
The language departments are screaming about not
enough funds to allow efficient operation of the new
language lab. Apparently money had been cut off the
budget. Can we see the figures? Dean Kimball feels our
interests should lie elsewhere. A large water main (not
serviced since 1921) breaks in the upper-class dormitories, making bathrooms unusable for a day.
And perhaps worst of all the famous 7c Levering
coffee now costs 10c. "I guess it's another of Taylor's
things," shrugs the counter woman.
In the academic realm, where student opinion seldom ventures, there is the strange case of the vanishing
pass-fail option. Last year the administration agreed
with rational arguments that such a system should be
institute at Hopkins on a trial basis. This year there is
not even a whisper about the pass-fail, even though most
colleges and universities of standing have adopted the
system.
The student arm of the administration, the Student
Council, has done little, if anything, to alleviate matters.
It could function as a focal point for organization of
student discontent and student action. Unfortunately it
is deep in its own brand of junior Establishment thinking—toying with such projects as dances and student
discounts.
Even though the undergraduate has only a four
year address al Hopkins, the urge to see change effected
and progress achieved is very strong. Student participation in intra-university affairs could be both an education and an experience. If a heritage is to be left at
Hopkins, if a history is to be built, it must be a joint
effort. If the administration continues to govern with a
curious mixture of whimsy and neglect, it will find contempt where respect should be.

The Nose Knows
Steve Shorter, rock hero of the recent British film
Privilege, was manipulated by a board of trustees and
the clergy to instill a religious fervor among the wayward youth of England.
We wonder, when we hear of the Beatles' latest
pronouncement that drugs can no longer hold a grass
joint to transcendental, metaphysical contemplation,
whether the Beatles themselves are being used to keep
the hippies of the Western World away from pot.
After -II, it rather boggles the mind to think of
Ringo sitting cross-legged in communication with his
inner self.

To the Editors:
So the jury is still out on Lincoln Gordon. We thought we
knew what he was about from
his speech to the freshman class
but now you come along and
give the impression, in your oblique way, that he might not
have meant what he said, quite.
And hence we are left to wonder
whether he is a genuine reactionary or simply an ordinary establishment figure who occasionally
sounds like one. One might also
wonder whether it matters.
The reason it does not matter
is that it is not Lincoln Gordon,
or anyone else in the Administration, who is going to do something toward bridging the very
considerable bap between what
Hopkins is and what a university
should be. That is simply not
what he is being paid a substantial salary to do. Lincoln Gordon,
whether he turns out to be a
liberal administrator or a repressive one, is going to try to insure that Hopkins remains a safe
place for the services to government and industry that seem to
be its raison d'etre. He and his
colleagues are going to oppose
any serious efforts made, by
"direct action" or otherwise, to
democratize the university, to
change its orientation or to force
it to come to terms with the
society around it. If it is only up
to Lincoln Gordon, Hopkins is
going to remain a de facto subsidiary of the State Department
and the Pentagon although if he
does his job well it may become
a bigger and better one.
What is needed therefore is for
students to start showing that
they care about this. The top priority for anyone who has pretensions to being a student lea-

der should be the creation of effective student structures, independent of all forms of outside
control, so that the voice of the
students on the campus can be
heard. The problems in student
organization at Hopkins are of a
very basic nature. They are also
of crucial importance because of
the magnitude of what has to be
done and the scope of what an
effective student union can
achieve.

with which Hopkins students
must come to grips, and soon.
Yours faithfully.
Robert Chodos

I Code: Stress On Honor
By DAVE BUCIIDAIII,
For several years now, the
Honor Commission has existed in
order to promote the ideals of
the Honor System and try those
individuals who have violated the
system by cheating. he rationale
behind the Commission is simply
that students should handle their
own affairs: and since cheating
cannot be condoned by the University, the apprehension, trial
and punishment of violators,
should be handled by the students rather than the faculty or
members of the administration.
The Honor Commission, therefore, tries cases and assigns penalties for academic violations. It
does not, however, attempt to
prevent cheating in any active
sense, except, perhaps, insofar as
it orients newcomers in our community. he prevention of cheating is a matter of individual concern, to be decided by each member of this community in accordance with his own attitudes and
inclinations.

Part of one's responsibility under the Honor Code is to report
suspected violators. This responsibility, however, is not on4
which the Honor Commission
can enforce. Nor is it one which
should be enforced by the Honor
Commission, for they have jurisdiction only over academic violations. Failure to report a violation, while it can be construed as
a violation of the Honor Code is
not an academic violation, and
will, for that reason, not be punishable by the H.C.
The change in this area was
approved by the Honor Commission for the reasons stated above.
The Honor System only works
and only makes sense if it has the
support of the student body. Part
of his support is turning in suspected violators. But while we
can punish violators, we must
distinguish between them and
non-supporters. There is a difference and it is a d.iierence
which should be recognized in
policy as well as in fact

I Republican
Bias

Dick's Chances: He May Make It Yet

Editors' note: this is the second
of a series of articles covering
the prospective candidates for
the Republican presidential nom:nation.
By KENNETH W. BOND
Usually when a man is nominated for the presidency and
then loses, he retires honorably
from political activity and becomes a pleasant household memory. But not Richard Nixon.
Nearly eight years after his narrow defeat to John Kennedy,
Dick Nixon is as much alive and
politically potent as ever. Indeed,
he is today the most boyant, if
not the most politically astute,
major Republican figure since
Teddy Roosevelt.
Part of Nixon's strength is due

to the fact that after his 1960
death blow he didn't die. In 1962
Pat Brown killed him again, but
Nixon has kept on fighting in
behalf of Republican candidates
all over the country. From the
Garden appearance to speeches
at grange picnics, Nixon has been
the foremost promoter of the
GOP in the '60s. As a result, he
has become the truly faithful Republican to the party faithful.
And today a lot of people owe
Dick Nixon quite a few favors.
In addition, during a time
when U.S. foreign policy has
crumbled at the hands of the
Viet Nam war, Nixon has projected himself as the free-lance
"internationalist" of the GOP. To
those who weigh foreign issues

heavier than domestic ones,
Nixon's experience in the foreign
affairs field makes him the most
well-qualified man to occupy the
White House.
But Nixon's grass-roots support
and respected image in foreign
matters will do him little good
at the 1968 GOP convention unless he overcomes a few stigmas
in the public eye, and unless
certain conditions prevail at
Miami Beach. First, Nixon is
stuck with a loser's image. Republicans in general have declining faith in his ability to win
an election. After all, the last
race he won was for his California Senate seat in 1950-17
years ago. If Nixon can't do well

in the coming state primaries,
his chances for nomination will
rapidly diminish. And unfortunately, the latest national polls
show Nixon as second or third
at best in popularity among fellow GOP contenders. As Nixon
said himself recently: "I have to
be dramatically effective in the
primaries, or I've had it." Second,
Nixon is often rated as a conservative ,with his voter strength
coming traditionally from conservative areas: the south and
midwest. Yet, the current idol for
energetic conservatives transferred from the Goldwater camp is
Ronald Reagan. This puts Nixon
in an embarrassing position.
Amazingly enough, however,
Richard Nixon could pull a NU-

ham Jennings Bryan by being
nominated for the same office he
ran for and was defeated for
eight years ago. If the 1968 Republican convention is "wide
open" as many political speculators predict (that is, if either
Rockefeller, Reagan, or Romney
can't have a majority of the delegation votes committed to him
by convention time as Goldwater
did), then Dick Nixon could become the GOP's best compromise
candidate. Rocky says he won't
play ball; Romney appears to be
hanging in limbo; and Reagan
and Chuck Percy are very new
political products. But Nixon is
well-known and time-tested.
Finally, it may be that the
American voter is in a more
sober mood today than he was
four or eight years ago. The
Communist threat is more than
a paper tiger in southeast Asia;
our cities are burning to the
rhythm of racial riots. Perhaps
1968 will be a year when Republicans and the electorate will buy
a proven candidate. someone they
trust to protect their national
and individual freedom. If this is
the case, then Richard Nixon
could be the W. J. Bryan who
made it the second time around.

HOlVIEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCTOBER 6, 1967

Harriers Open
With New Coach
The 1967 varsity cross-country
team will open its campaign
against Loyola in an away meet
on Tuesday, October 10.
Under the guidance of rookie
coach Don Marken the Hopkins
harriers are attempting to im
prove on a dismal performance
last season. Mr. Masken comes to
Hopkins with impressive credentials. He ran for City College anc
co-captained a Towson State
team. Following graduation he
headed the Chesapeake Track
Club and served as chairman of
the South Atlantic Track Association.
When asked of his team's prospects ,the youthful coach snapped, "great." Training consists of
ten miles a day in preparation
for the grueling four mile race.
Fortunately the new coach has a
roster of dedicated athletes in an
unheralded sport.
Seniors Cliff Cyr and Jerry Danoff are co-captains. The other returning lettermen are Jeff Lauren
and John Gardinger. Yet to run
in varsity competition are sophomores John McKeon and John
Wilkens. Hopefully this promising team will take its share of
victories during the eight-meet
1967 season.

Varsity Basketball
Varsity basketball practice
will start on Tuesday, October
17. Anyone interested in playing, managing, or keeping statistics should report to the
Athletic Center classroom at
4:30 p.m. on that date.

NEWS -LETTER

JAY'S NEST
By JIM SLOAN
One could hardly blame Franklin and Marshall if they try to
find another opponent to open
the football season against next
year.
Although last years' hapless
Hopkins' gridmen were unable to
capture a victory under first year
Coach Alex Sotir, the Jays managed to come up with a tie in the
opener against F&M (14-14). Last
Saturday they traveled to Lancaster to face the Diplomats for
the initial outing of the 1967
campaign.
The action there featured a
successful on-side kickoff, ex
plosive running by backs Joe
Cowan and Paul Weiss, and a
solid Jay defensive line. Quarter
back Jim Feely commanded the
offensive squad impressively and
displayed potential as an accurate and effective passer. A last
minute touchdown gave the Blue
Jays the win of the most exciting
football contest Hopkins has
played in recent years.
The F&M victory, of course,
gives rise to promise for a winning season. The Jays host Ursinus tomorrow in their home
opener with much improved
chances of victory. Fullback
Mark Croft, last year's leading
ground gainer, was sidelined last
Saturday with a sprained arch.
The chances for his return look
to be good. Other improvements
also point to a favorable result in
tomorrow's contest.
It is of course, pleasant to be
able to welcome the Class of 1971

on the encouraging note set by
last week's victory. In this vain
I would call attention to a general increase in the quality of the
Hopkins' sports program.
Last year's statistics will serve
to demonstrate an overall improvement in the won-lost tally
of most teams. Lacrosse (10-1)
sported one of its best seasons
in recent years. Fencing copped
a winning season, and basketball
was a near miss at 8-9. The
swimming team, realizing the
benefits of the new aquatic facilities, captured its first victory in
many seasons.
Improved schedules also witness a greater emphasis on
sports. Soccer has added the Machamps,
Southern
son-Dixon
Lynchburg. The Jay basketball
team plays Navy (Jan. 9) for the
first time. The swimming and
fencing squads have both added
Penn State to their cards.
These changes, though they
may indicate a vibrant sports
program and may appear encouraging, should not be overemphasized. For the administration and
probably the players also, sports
at Hopkins shall remain a secondary consideration in the total unIPT-Tra dna te picture.

potential at guard).

URSINUS IS NEXT—Preparing for their second straight victory, Blue Jay offensive linemen sharpen

'New Look' Football Squad
Off To Best Start In Years
By MIKE PHILLIPS
Braced by an opening-game victory—its first win since 1965—
the varsity football team gets a
chance to display its "new look"
offensive capabilities to home
fans tomorrow when its hosts Urp.m.
sinus at
The Bears, who tied Muhlenburg (a four touchdown scrimmage loser to Hopkins) 6-6 last
week return 19 lettermen from
the group that edged the Jays
22-20 a year ago. With experienced performers available at
most key positions, they should
provide rougher opposition than
the above comparative scores
would tend to indicate.
Ursinus quarterback Pete D'Achille, a 6-0 senior who hit on
seven of seventeen passes (one
for a 55 yard T.D.) against Hopkins in 466, can throw well both
long and short; and he has an
excellent target in the person of
5-8, 155 pound soph backfield
mate Joe Corvaia, also a capable
runner (77 yards on 16 carries
against Muhlenberg). Rounding
out the Bear backfield are 5-8,
155 pound soph halfback Greg
Adams—a capable runner and receiver— and junior fullback Jim
McDonald (44 yards on seven carries last week).
Leading the way for this unit
is a veteran offensive line which
averages 194 pounds per man and

possesses two more capable receivers for D'Achille's tosses in
6-1, 180 pound split end John
Tracey and 6-1, 185 pound Tom
Addicks. The defense, which allowed Muhlenberg only one score
(as compared to at least two
T.D.'s against Hopkins), should
also be fairly effective.
J.H.U. football took one of its
rosier hues of recent years last
Saturday, when the Jay contingent—displaying the makings of
a potent offense and getting effective defensive performances from
several newcomers—staged a 1914 comeback win over Franklin
and Marshall.
Cowan Rambles
Junior Joe Cowan, three years
absent from the grid wars, made
his presence felt in a hurry in
that game, as he took a handoff
from Paul Weiss on the opening
kickoff and moved 88 yards to
stake his teammates to a 6-0 lead.
Hopkins, twice driving inside the
F&M 20 yard line but failing to
score, dominated the entire first
period; and it was not until the
end of the half that the Diplomats, after a 50 yard drive, got
the score that put them ahead
7-6.
The offensive impetus went
back to the Homewood squad in
the third period, as two stalled
drives resulted in field goals of
38 (line of scrimmage 21) and

By BOB HYAMS
The varsity soccer team kicks
off the season this year against
Delaware on Tuesday, October 8,
at 3 p.m. with chances of a winning season hinging on the contributions of sophomores.
If the sophomores do their job
in every ball game, the Jays have
a good chance to come out number one. Coach Barrette opined,
"the team has good talent, great
spirit, but experience looks to be
a big factor." Foreign players,
especially on Swarthmore and
Drexel have a lot more experience
than the Jays and everything is
put squarely on the sophomores'
shoulders.
Starters Cited
The team consists of nine
sophomores, eight juniors, and
five seniors, with eleven returning lettermen. Starting linemen
are co-captain Wes Bachur, Kit
Battenfield, Art Guerin, and Lou
Sardella. The starting backs are
co-captain John Sarney, John
Clisham, Randy Miller, Roger
Purdon, Dave Rockwell, and Rick
Tobey. The goalie position is still
in doubt as Mike Avery has a bad
ankle. He will probably alternate
with Pete Martindale.
The graduation of Pablo Drob
ny means a big scoring loss and
also a defensive loss as the defense was formerly stacked up on
him. However, if the sophs do
their job, things look very bright
as the team is more diversified
than ever before. The halfback
slot is a crucial spot and sophs
Randy Miller and Rick Tobey are
good prospects. Dave Roberts
and Josh Gerberer are the first
line replacements and the first
back substitute is Ken Torrington. Chris Gordon is lost for the
season due to illness.

The Waiting Wall
In a revealing statement last week, Dean Allyn Kimball both substantiated our suspicions and damned the
administration at the same time. Students, according to
the good Dean, should keep their noses out of such
matters as institutional finances and mind their own
business.
This unfortunate expression of the subconscious
reaffirms our view that the student is only an incidental guest at Hopkins. It would be wise to remember
that an administration is only a glorified janitor, making sure all the parts are running to the satisfaction of
the scholars and students.
There is a phenomenon in social theory that explains the syndrome of the Hopkins administration. It
seems that organizations are created to reach goals.
When they lose sight of their goal, or become sidetracked, the organization often works only to perpetuate itself. Apparently this is what has happened to the
Hopkins administration—a situation whereby both student and scholar are seriously threatened.
We humble students have entrusted this institution
vilith the responsibility to educate us, and it seems that
at a crisp $2,000 per annum the administration could
accommodate us. Instead, at every corner we see blunder
after blunder. And when we ask why, we are told it is
not our business. What goes on behind the green door?
For instance, why does Whitehead Hall and Plant
Manager Wesley Taylor siphon off $240 from the food
allowance of subscribers to the Kosher Dining Hall?
"For overhead" we are told. What overhead? The students are paying for everything in this project.
The language departments are screaming about not
enough funds to allow efficient operation of the new
language lab. Apparently money had been cut off the
budget. Can we see the figures? Dean Kimball feels our
interests should lie elsewhere. A large water main (not
serviced since 1921) breaks in the upper-class dormitories, making bathrooms unusable for a day.
And perhaps worst of all the famous 7c Levering
coffee now costs 10c. "I guess it's another of Taylor's
things," shrugs the counter woman.
In the academic realm, where student opinion seldom ventures, there is the strange case of the vanishing
pass-fail option. Last year the administration agreed
with rational arguments that such a system should be
institute at Hopkins on a trial basis. This year there is
not even a whisper about the pass-fail, even though most
colleges and universities of standing have adopted the
system.
The student arm of the administration, the Student
Council, has done little, if anything, to alleviate matters.
It could function as a focal point for organization of
student discontent and student action. Unfortunately it
is deep in its own brand of junior Establishment thinking—toying with such projects as dances and student
discounts.
Even though the undergraduate has only a four
year address al Hopkins, the urge to see change effected
and progress achieved is very strong. Student participation in intra-university affairs could be both an education and an experience. If a heritage is to be left at
Hopkins, if a history is to be built, it must be a joint
effort. If the administration continues to govern with a
curious mixture of whimsy and neglect, it will find contempt where respect should be.

The Nose Knows
Steve Shorter, rock hero of the recent British film
Privilege, was manipulated by a board of trustees and
the clergy to instill a religious fervor among the wayward youth of England.
We wonder, when we hear of the Beatles' latest
pronouncement that drugs can no longer hold a grass
joint to transcendental, metaphysical contemplation,
whether the Beatles themselves are being used to keep
the hippies of the Western World away from pot.
After -II, it rather boggles the mind to think of
Ringo sitting cross-legged in communication with his
inner self.

To the Editors:
So the jury is still out on Lincoln Gordon. We thought we
knew what he was about from
his speech to the freshman class
but now you come along and
give the impression, in your oblique way, that he might not
have meant what he said, quite.
And hence we are left to wonder
whether he is a genuine reactionary or simply an ordinary establishment figure who occasionally
sounds like one. One might also
wonder whether it matters.
The reason it does not matter
is that it is not Lincoln Gordon,
or anyone else in the Administration, who is going to do something toward bridging the very
considerable bap between what
Hopkins is and what a university
should be. That is simply not
what he is being paid a substantial salary to do. Lincoln Gordon,
whether he turns out to be a
liberal administrator or a repressive one, is going to try to insure that Hopkins remains a safe
place for the services to government and industry that seem to
be its raison d'etre. He and his
colleagues are going to oppose
any serious efforts made, by
"direct action" or otherwise, to
democratize the university, to
change its orientation or to force
it to come to terms with the
society around it. If it is only up
to Lincoln Gordon, Hopkins is
going to remain a de facto subsidiary of the State Department
and the Pentagon although if he
does his job well it may become
a bigger and better one.
What is needed therefore is for
students to start showing that
they care about this. The top priority for anyone who has pretensions to being a student lea-

der should be the creation of effective student structures, independent of all forms of outside
control, so that the voice of the
students on the campus can be
heard. The problems in student
organization at Hopkins are of a
very basic nature. They are also
of crucial importance because of
the magnitude of what has to be
done and the scope of what an
effective student union can
achieve.

with which Hopkins students
must come to grips, and soon.
Yours faithfully.
Robert Chodos

By DAVE BUCIIDAIII,
For several years now, the
Honor Commission has existed in
order to promote the ideals of
the Honor System and try those
individuals who have violated the
system by cheating. he rationale
behind the Commission is simply
that students should handle their
own affairs: and since cheating
cannot be condoned by the University, the apprehension, trial
and punishment of violators,
should be handled by the students rather than the faculty or
members of the administration.
The Honor Commission, therefore, tries cases and assigns penalties for academic violations. It
does not, however, attempt to
prevent cheating in any active
sense, except, perhaps, insofar as
it orients newcomers in our community. he prevention of cheating is a matter of individual concern, to be decided by each member of this community in accordance with his own attitudes and
inclinations.

Part of one's responsibility under the Honor Code is to report
suspected violators. This responsibility, however, is not on4
which the Honor Commission
can enforce. Nor is it one which
should be enforced by the Honor
Commission, for they have jurisdiction only over academic violations. Failure to report a violation, while it can be construed as
a violation of the Honor Code is
not an academic violation, and
will, for that reason, not be punishable by the H.C.
The change in this area was
approved by the Honor Commission for the reasons stated above.
The Honor System only works
and only makes sense if it has the
support of the student body. Part
of his support is turning in suspected violators. But while we
can punish violators, we must
distinguish between them and
non-supporters. There is a difference and it is a d.iierence
which should be recognized in

Dick's Chances: He May Make It Yet

Editors' note: this is the second
of a series of articles covering
the prospective candidates for
the Republican presidential nom:nation.
By KENNETH W. BOND
Usually when a man is nominated for the presidency and
then loses, he retires honorably
from political activity and becomes a pleasant household memory. But not Richard Nixon.
Nearly eight years after his narrow defeat to John Kennedy,
Dick Nixon is as much alive and
politically potent as ever. Indeed,
he is today the most boyant, if
not the most politically astute,
major Republican figure since
Teddy Roosevelt.
Part of Nixon's strength is due

to the fact that after his 1960
death blow he didn't die. In 1962
Pat Brown killed him again, but
Nixon has kept on fighting in
behalf of Republican candidates
all over the country. From the
Garden appearance to speeches
at grange picnics, Nixon has been
the foremost promoter of the
GOP in the '60s. As a result, he
has become the truly faithful Republican to the party faithful.
And today a lot of people owe
Dick Nixon quite a few favors.
In addition, during a time
when U.S. foreign policy has
crumbled at the hands of the
Viet Nam war, Nixon has projected himself as the free-lance
"internationalist" of the GOP. To
those who weigh foreign issues

heavier than domestic ones,
Nixon's experience in the foreign
affairs field makes him the most
well-qualified man to occupy the
White House.
But Nixon's grass-roots support
and respected image in foreign
matters will do him little good
at the 1968 GOP convention unless he overcomes a few stigmas
in the public eye, and unless
certain conditions prevail at
Miami Beach. First, Nixon is
stuck with a loser's image. Republicans in general have declining faith in his ability to win
an election. After all, the last
race he won was for his California Senate seat in 1950-17
years ago. If Nixon can't do well

in the coming state primaries,
his chances for nomination will
rapidly diminish. And unfortunately, the latest national polls
show Nixon as second or third
at best in popularity among fellow GOP contenders. As Nixon
said himself recently: "I have to
be dramatically effective in the
primaries, or I've had it." Second,
Nixon is often rated as a conservative ,with his voter strength
coming traditionally from conservative areas: the south and
midwest. Yet, the current idol for
energetic conservatives transferred from the Goldwater camp is
Ronald Reagan. This puts Nixon
in an embarrassing position.
Amazingly enough, however,
Richard Nixon could pull a NU-

ham Jennings Bryan by being
nominated for the same office he
ran for and was defeated for
eight years ago. If the 1968 Republican convention is "wide
open" as many political speculators predict (that is, if either
Rockefeller, Reagan, or Romney
can't have a majority of the delegation votes committed to him
by convention time as Goldwater
did), then Dick Nixon could become the GOP's best compromise
candidate. Rocky says he won't
play ball; Romney appears to be
hanging in limbo; and Reagan
and Chuck Percy are very new
political products. But Nixon is
well-known and time-tested.
Finally, it may be that the
American voter is in a more
sober mood today than he was
four or eight years ago. The
Communist threat is more than
a paper tiger in southeast Asia;
our cities are burning to the
rhythm of racial riots. Perhaps
1968 will be a year when Republicans and the electorate will buy
a proven candidate. someone they
trust to protect their national
and individual freedom. If this is
the case, then Richard Nixon
could be the W. J. Bryan who
made it the second time around.

HOlVIEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCTOBER 6, 1967

Harriers Open
With New Coach
The 1967 varsity cross-country
team will open its campaign
against Loyola in an away meet
on Tuesday, October 10.
Under the guidance of rookie
coach Don Marken the Hopkins
harriers are attempting to im
prove on a dismal performance
last season. Mr. Masken comes to
Hopkins with impressive credentials. He ran for City College anc
co-captained a Towson State
team. Following graduation he
headed the Chesapeake Track
Club and served as chairman of
the South Atlantic Track Association.
When asked of his team's prospects ,the youthful coach snapped, "great." Training consists of
ten miles a day in preparation
for the grueling four mile race.
Fortunately the new coach has a
roster of dedicated athletes in an
unheralded sport.
Seniors Cliff Cyr and Jerry Danoff are co-captains. The other returning lettermen are Jeff Lauren
and John Gardinger. Yet to run
in varsity competition are sophomores John McKeon and John
Wilkens. Hopefully this promising team will take its share of
victories during the eight-meet
1967 season.

Varsity Basketball
Varsity basketball practice
will start on Tuesday, October
17. Anyone interested in playing, managing, or keeping statistics should report to the
Athletic Center classroom at
4:30 p.m. on that date.

NEWS -LETTER

JAY'S NEST
By JIM SLOAN
One could hardly blame Franklin and Marshall if they try to
find another opponent to open
the football season against next
year.
Although last years' hapless
Hopkins' gridmen were unable to
capture a victory under first year
Coach Alex Sotir, the Jays managed to come up with a tie in the
opener against F&M (14-14). Last
Saturday they traveled to Lancaster to face the Diplomats for
the initial outing of the 1967
campaign.
The action there featured a
successful on-side kickoff, ex
plosive running by backs Joe
Cowan and Paul Weiss, and a
solid Jay defensive line. Quarter
back Jim Feely commanded the
offensive squad impressively and
displayed potential as an accurate and effective passer. A last
minute touchdown gave the Blue
Jays the win of the most exciting
football contest Hopkins has
played in recent years.
The F&M victory, of course,
gives rise to promise for a winning season. The Jays host Ursinus tomorrow in their home
opener with much improved
chances of victory. Fullback
Mark Croft, last year's leading
ground gainer, was sidelined last
Saturday with a sprained arch.
The chances for his return look
to be good. Other improvements
also point to a favorable result in
tomorrow's contest.
It is of course, pleasant to be
able to welcome the Class of 1971

on the encouraging note set by
last week's victory. In this vain
I would call attention to a general increase in the quality of the
Hopkins' sports program.
Last year's statistics will serve
to demonstrate an overall improvement in the won-lost tally
of most teams. Lacrosse (10-1)
sported one of its best seasons
in recent years. Fencing copped
a winning season, and basketball
was a near miss at 8-9. The
swimming team, realizing the
benefits of the new aquatic facilities, captured its first victory in
many seasons.
Improved schedules also witness a greater emphasis on
sports. Soccer has added the Machamps,
Southern
son-Dixon
Lynchburg. The Jay basketball
team plays Navy (Jan. 9) for the
first time. The swimming and
fencing squads have both added
Penn State to their cards.
These changes, though they
may indicate a vibrant sports
program and may appear encouraging, should not be overemphasized. For the administration and
probably the players also, sports
at Hopkins shall remain a secondary consideration in the total unIPT-Tra dna te picture.

Freshman Basketball

Freshman Gridders Show
Talents and Experience
Increased experience and depth
at critical positions will be the
keynote of the 1967 freshman
football campaign.
All but five of the Baby Jays
sport high school experience. As
a group ,the 32-man squad shows
more depth than freshman teams
of past seasons.
The quarterbacks include two
local men, Bob Pfeifer and Dan
Augustine, who are in contention
for the starting assignment. The
roster also lists Dave Nolan as a
QB. Four Baby Jays are listed
for the fullback slot. Steve Hata
looks to be the starter, and others are Craig Moore, Ed Dunbar,
and Bob Hacher.

The tailbacks include Doug Pelton, Jeff Quartner ,and Dave
Clark. Wingbacks are Pete Zangara, David Asken, Bob Kelley,
and Ken Dauses. The ends are
Doug Hein, Frank Bruzzese, Pete
Miller, Ed Kardas, Dwight Johnson, and Ed Kadyszewski.
Contenders for the tackle assignment will be Bill Knapp.
Doug Krabbenhoft, Keven Hagan,
Dan Johnson, Al Jewett, and Tim
Meiller. The probable guards are
Jim McMenamin, Dennis Lanahan, Mike Foley, and Mike Teller.
Finally, the position at center
will go to either Gus Slotman or
Tom Sawyer (also a first line
potential at guard).

'New Look' Football Squad
Off To Best Start In Years
By MIKE PHILLIPS
Braced by an opening-game victory—its first win since 1965—
the varsity football team gets a
chance to display its "new look"
offensive capabilities to home
fans tomorrow when its hosts Urp.m.
sinus at
The Bears, who tied Muhlenburg (a four touchdown scrimmage loser to Hopkins) 6-6 last
week return 19 lettermen from
the group that edged the Jays
22-20 a year ago. With experienced performers available at
most key positions, they should
provide rougher opposition than
the above comparative scores
would tend to indicate.
Ursinus quarterback Pete D'Achille, a 6-0 senior who hit on
seven of seventeen passes (one
for a 55 yard T.D.) against Hopkins in 466, can throw well both
long and short; and he has an
excellent target in the person of
5-8, 155 pound soph backfield
mate Joe Corvaia, also a capable
runner (77 yards on 16 carries
against Muhlenberg). Rounding
out the Bear backfield are 5-8,
155 pound soph halfback Greg
Adams—a capable runner and receiver— and junior fullback Jim
McDonald (44 yards on seven carries last week).
Leading the way for this unit
is a veteran offensive line which
averages 194 pounds per man and

possesses two more capable receivers for D'Achille's tosses in
6-1, 180 pound split end John
Tracey and 6-1, 185 pound Tom
Addicks. The defense, which allowed Muhlenberg only one score
(as compared to at least two
T.D.'s against Hopkins), should
also be fairly effective.
J.H.U. football took one of its
rosier hues of recent years last
Saturday, when the Jay contingent—displaying the makings of
a potent offense and getting effective defensive performances from
several newcomers—staged a 1914 comeback win over Franklin
and Marshall.
Cowan Rambles
Junior Joe Cowan, three years
absent from the grid wars, made
his presence felt in a hurry in
that game, as he took a handoff
from Paul Weiss on the opening
kickoff and moved 88 yards to

Hopkins, twice driving inside the
F&M 20 yard line but failing to
score, dominated the entire first
period; and it was not until the
end of the half that the Diplomats, after a 50 yard drive, got
the score that put them ahead
7-6.
The offensive impetus went
back to the Homewood squad in
the third period, as two stalled
drives resulted in field goals of

By BOB HYAMS
The varsity soccer team kicks
off the season this year against
Delaware on Tuesday, October 8,
at 3 p.m. with chances of a winning season hinging on the contributions of sophomores.
If the sophomores do their job
in every ball game, the Jays have
a good chance to come out number one. Coach Barrette opined,
"the team has good talent, great
spirit, but experience looks to be
a big factor." Foreign players,
especially on Swarthmore and
Drexel have a lot more experience
than the Jays and everything is
put squarely on the sophomores'
shoulders.
Starters Cited
The team consists of nine
sophomores, eight juniors, and
five seniors, with eleven returning lettermen. Starting linemen
are co-captain Wes Bachur, Kit
Battenfield, Art Guerin, and Lou
Sardella. The starting backs are
co-captain John Sarney, John
Clisham, Randy Miller, Roger
Purdon, Dave Rockwell, and Rick
Tobey. The goalie position is still
in doubt as Mike Avery has a bad
ankle. He will probably alternate
with Pete Martindale.
The graduation of Pablo Drob
ny means a big scoring loss and
also a defensive loss as the defense was formerly stacked up on
him. However, if the sophs do
their job, things look very bright
as the team is more diversified
than ever before. The halfback
slot is a crucial spot and sophs
Randy Miller and Rick Tobey are
good prospects. Dave Roberts
and Josh Gerberer are the first
line replacements and the first
back substitute is Ken Torrington. Chris Gordon is lost for the
season due to illness.
